options: Converting continuous-domain problems into discrete-point problems
questions.correctAnswer: Converting continuous-domain problems into discrete-point problems
questions.explanation: Discretization changes the domain from continuous to discrete. You go from x(t) defined at every instant to x[n] defined only at sample times. The key attribute is creating a countable representation of something inherently continuous.

questions.prompt: The forward finite difference approximation df/dx ≈ (f(x+h) − f(x))/h has error order:
questions.explanation: The forward difference has O(h) error — it's first-order accurate. Halving h halves the error. This comes from the Taylor expansion: f(x+h) = f(x) + hf'(x) + h²f''(x)/2 + ..., so (f(x+h)−f(x))/h = f'(x) + O(h).

questions.prompt: The central second difference formula is:
questions.explanation: The central second difference approximates d²f/dx² using three points: f at x−h, x, and x+h. The formula (f(x+h) − 2f(x) + f(x−h))/h² has O(h²) error. This is used extensively in solving PDEs like Laplace's equation on a grid.

The DFT takes N discrete time samples x[n] and produces N discrete frequency samples X[k]. Both the time domain (x(t) → x[n]) and frequency domain (X(f) → X[k]) are discretized. The frequency resolution is Δf = fs/N.

questions.prompt: In the discretized Laplace equation on a 2D grid, how many neighbors does each interior point depend on?
questions.explanation: The 5-point stencil for Laplace's equation uses V[i,j] and its 4 nearest neighbors: V[i+1,j], V[i−1,j], V[i,j+1], V[i,j−1]. This is the standard discretization for the Laplacian ∇²V = ∂²V/∂x² + ∂²V/∂y² on a uniform grid.

questions.prompt: A 100×100 grid for Laplace's equation produces how many unknowns?
questions.explanation: Each grid point is an unknown, and a 100×100 grid has 100 × 100 = 10,000 points (minus boundary points which are known, but the order of magnitude is 10,000). This gives a system of ~10,000 linear equations — large but solvable for modern computers.

questions.prompt: Why is central difference (O(h²)) preferred over forward difference (O(h))?
options: It's more accurate for the same grid spacing h
questions.correctAnswer: It's more accurate for the same grid spacing h
questions.explanation: Central differences use symmetric information (points on both sides), which cancels the leading error term by symmetry. For the same h, central differences are typically much more accurate. Forward differences are only used when boundary conditions prevent using the symmetric formula.

questions.prompt: The frequency resolution of an N-point DFT with sampling rate fs is:
questions.explanation: The DFT produces N frequency bins from 0 to fs, spaced at intervals of Δf = fs/N. Want 1 Hz resolution with fs = 1000 Hz? You need N = 1000 samples. This is why longer recordings give finer frequency resolution.

questions.prompt: Does sampling at exactly the Nyquist rate always give perfect reconstruction?
options: No — it gives the mathematical minimum; practical systems need some margin above Nyquist
Yes, but only for DC signals
questions.correctAnswer: No — it gives the mathematical minimum; practical systems need some margin above Nyquist
questions.explanation: The Nyquist rate (2·fmax) is the theoretical minimum. In practice, anti-aliasing filters are imperfect, so you sample somewhat above Nyquist. CD audio uses fs = 44.1 kHz for 20 kHz audio bandwidth — about 10% above the Nyquist minimum of 40 kHz.

questions.prompt: What type of error does discretization primarily introduce?
questions.explanation: Discretization introduces aliasing (when sampling below Nyquist) and discretization error (from replacing continuous operations with discrete approximations, like derivatives with finite differences). These are fundamentally different from statistical error (random sampling) or linearization error (local validity).
